title: What differentiates a good English teacher from a bad English teacher? - Quora

response.answer_text: There's no concise answer to this - generally a teacher with a positive stance - who enjoys teaching - who enjoys people - ultimately creates a more positive classroom environment. Students feeling discouraged, disheartened - students who are overly criticized rather than encouraged - don't do as well in a foreign language class. When we speak - in our home language - we open ourselves. Speaking up, sharing your thoughts and opinions - can make people feel vulnerable. Speaking up can feel risky - what reaction will people have to what you say? When you're speaking in a foreign language classroom - students can feel very insecure, very uncertain. Many students have the underlying fear that they will be laughed at - they'll say something in the wrong way, they'll use the wrong word and so they're reluctant to speak at all. Pouncing on students for their grammatical errors can make students feel more insecure and more uncertain. What's the teacher's attitude toward English? Toward language learning? Do they enjoy it? Do they see language as a great adventure - or is it a chore forced on them by changing global realities? The good English teacher is positive - toward learners, toward those trying to learn English, and enjoys teaching in general as well as teaching English.

Getting into more objective technical skills, I would say a good English teacher has or can… Elicits and concept checks (CCQ) target language wellIs engagingHas clear language goals for the lesson/semesterHas clear ways of checking that students have reached these goals (tests/evaluations)Has empathy! Understands what the students need and why they need itSolid understanding of English grammarAbility to create high STT that’s authentic sounding and relevant to studentsGood time managementUses an economy of language (doesn’t just ramble through lessons)Brisk paceThose are few.
